reviews.author: Sarah Cortinaz

reviews.author: Cory Woodroof

reviews.author: Anna Swanson

reviews.author: Trace Thurman

reviews.author: Tomris Laffly

reviews.text: The Invisible Man gives terrifying shape to an all-too-real villain. It proves that a smart script, committed director, and talented actors can be a far more powerful vehicle for classic horror than a paint-by-numbers franchise reboot.
reviews.author: Hannah Lodge

reviews.text: The movie clenches the imaginary of the abused woman between the memory of 70s revenge stories, the analog esthetic of 90s thrillers, and a new search, focused on Elizabeth Moss' extraordinary expressions. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Paula Vázquez Prieto

reviews.text: Whannell makes a wise choice emphasizing the plight of Cecilia, rather than the tired old clichés of an invisible man running amok. It makes it easier for the audience to accept the premise and identify with Cecilia's situation.
reviews.author: Bob Bloom

reviews.text: A golly-whopper psycho-thriller of a horror show that's also a monster movie for the #MeToo movement, a creep show about toxic masculinity and how abused women are often told they're crazy.
reviews.author: Neil Pond

reviews.text: Terrifying, unique, and one of the best horror experiences this year.
reviews.author: Adam Patterson

reviews.text: The Invisible Man reverberates as a bold and thrilling addition to the genre.
reviews.author: Euan Franklin

reviews.text: Elisabeth Moss delivers an outstanding performance as a woman teetering on the edge of reality in this thoroughly engaging reboot.
reviews.author: Linda Marric

reviews.text: A thoroughly modern makeover of HG Wells' idea, with everything geared to generate armrest-clutching moments of suspense and to deliver a fistful of high-voltage shocks designed to jolt you in your seat - and possibly out of it.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: Moss finds in Cecelia both a vulnerable victim and a fed-up fighter who can outfight and outthink her unseen tormentor, and her performance turns "The Invisible Man" into something deeper than a standard horror movie.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: The Invisible Man does run a little long, and momentarily loses its footing in its final movement, but for the most part confirms that there is a place for Universal monsters in today's dark universe.
reviews.author: James Marsh

reviews.text: Another offering from the Blumhouse factory of sameness.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: There's nothing hollow about this man. [Leigh Whannell] has a clear vision, and he executes it with terror-filled grace while also unveiling another superhuman Elisabeth Moss performance.
reviews.author: Preston Barta

reviews.text: This is one screenplay that needed, well, a little more vision.
reviews.author: Sara Stewart

reviews.text: Doesn't quite stick the landing story-wise, but still boasts a phenomenal performance from Elisabeth Moss and more proof that Leigh Whannell has a stellar eye for highly creative and effective scares and action.
reviews.author: Perri Nemiroff

reviews.text: With The Invisible Man, Whannell has reminded us just how effective even the most familiar horror can still be when done right.
reviews.author: Tyler Smith

reviews.text: The Invisible Man interlocks the real-world distress felt by many women, while giving face to the demons men would rather think only exist in handfuls today.
reviews.author: Robert Daniels

reviews.text: It taps into so many primal fears...More akin to a classic psychological thriller than the forgettable horror film that it could have been.
reviews.author: Dan Murrell

reviews.text: Leigh Whannell, who made the wildly entertaining, low-budget action film "Upgrade," has turned the classic science-fiction tale inside out and fashioned it into a tense, suspenseful story about a brutalized woman's journey from seclusion to visibility.
reviews.author: Cary Darling

reviews.text: With devastating specificity and empathy for his heroine, Whannell has inverted the invisible man archetype into an incredibly tense and suspenseful thriller exploring the psychological horror of intimate partner abuse.
reviews.author: Katie Walsh

reviews.text: Leigh Whannell's monster movie works so well because he has such a recognizable monster.
reviews.author: Matt Goldberg

reviews.text: Perfectly-timed horror examining the impact of psychological and domestic abuse, the long shadow it casts, and a particularly recognisable vile strain of masculinity.
reviews.author: Steve Newall

reviews.text: Elisabeth Moss is an acting event all by herself, a modern version of Bette Davis, and "The Invisible Man" gives her a chance to embody all kinds of emotional extremes - terror, dread, madness, inconsolable grief and murderous rage.
reviews.author: Mick LaSalle

reviews.text: Leigh Whannell's The Invisible Man draws from multiple Blumhouse catalog influences to ensure a chilling monster remake with ferocity and urgency at its core.
reviews.author: Matt Donato

reviews.text: As ingenious a reinvention of an old film as has been made in the last decade in Hollywood.
reviews.author: Matt Singer

reviews.text: Icy art-horror style, shocking violence, and a smart understanding of the story's acute metaphorical resonance
reviews.author: Andrew Wyatt

reviews.text: Whannell still manages to deliver an impeccably crafted thriller that touches on the lingering effects of trauma, and the catharsis that comes from facing your demons head-on.
reviews.author: Clint Worthington

reviews.text: Moss's full-bore performance - anchored by her extraordinarily supple face - gives the movie its emotional stakes.
reviews.author: Manohla Dargis

reviews.text: The Invisible Man manages to do what many of our greatest horror movies have done before it: address a real-life, everyday nightmare in a heightened, bracing, and even cathartic way.
reviews.author: Allison Shoemaker

reviews.text: The Invisible Man is as thoughtful as it is entertaining, as disturbing as it is frightening, and stays with you after you leave the theater. This is a great film.
reviews.author: Alan Cerny

reviews.text: Move along: there's nothing to see here.
reviews.author: Nicholas Barber

reviews.text: Rare is it that one of the classic tales from the golden age gets a solid re-imagining, but this is one of those times. It's a more intimate story rather than madman wanting to rule the world, and it [mostly] works.
reviews.author: Bill Watters

reviews.text: Moss' intensity is almost too much for the film, which otherwise has a self-conscious B-movie mode, with sparsely dressed sets, expressionistic sound design and few concessions to realism.
reviews.author: Jake Wilson

reviews.text: [Moss] still holds her own as the movie crumbles around her, but her performance deserves better than what Whannell ultimately gives her.
reviews.author: Richard Lawson

reviews.text: A thought-provoking horror-thriller that focuses on the realities of emotional violence and abuse, particularly when it is painstakingly obscured.
reviews.author: Matt Oakes

reviews.text: A seriously potent psychological thriller that maximizes the suspense and violence in ways that leave you breathless. Whannell makes updating a classic look so easy, which is no small feat.
reviews.author: Meagan Navarro

reviews.text: Although too much of the final half-hour feels like a cookie-cutter collage of familiar moments, it delivers an adequate main course for a time of the year in which movies of this genre clog the box office.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: The film opens by dropping us right down in escape. Cecelia (Moss) is getting away from her abusive Frankenstein-tall monster of a husband (Oliver Jackson-Cohen, scarcely glimpsed in the flesh) by any means necessary. It's electric.
reviews.author: Jason Adams

reviews.text: A smart and satisfyingly nasty piece of work...
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: A strong lead performance from Elisabeth Moss and several well-timed scares deliver the frightful goods.
reviews.author: Julian Roman

reviews.text: It's twisty and super tense and, in an age where blockbusters are so full of visual effects, it's miraculous to find one that revels in what's not there.
reviews.author: Larushka Ivan-Zadeh

reviews.text: Moss holds the film together with her deeply committed performance, and in particular with the defeated air that she gives Cecilia, one that's always there under her recovering cheerfulness or displays of brittle defiance.
reviews.author: Alison Willmore

reviews.text: In The Invisible Man reboot Elisabeth Moss is visibly great in the movie that is not only perfectly timed for the #MeToo era, but also resonates far beyond the 1933 horror classic that inspired it.
reviews.author: Pete Hammond

reviews.text: One of the more enjoyable and intense psychological thrillers I've seen in a while.
reviews.author: Jeremy Jahns

reviews.text: "The Invisible Man" is riveting. As much a look at gaslighting and trauma as it is a vehicle for a classic Universal monster, it's top notch. Elisabeth Moss is terrific, too.
reviews.author: Joey Magidson

reviews.text: The Invisible Man has done well to reveal some positive light on this dark universe.
reviews.author: Aaron Neuwirth

reviews.text: The Invisible Man is a surprisingly modern, fresh take on a classic monster
reviews.author: Mike Ryan

reviews.text: While this isn't the story we're used to, Whannell's The Invisible Man might just be the story we need.
reviews.author: Kate Sánchez

reviews.text: [Elizabeth] Moss... is superb and convincing as a woman suffering from psychological anguish.
reviews.author: Jasmine Lim

reviews.text: Repeat viewings might expose further holes in the story, but Whannell remains a highly skilled genre filmmaker. As for Blumhouse, it's hard to think of another studio that currently knows its audience as well as they do.
reviews.author: Hannah Strong

reviews.text: This edgy psychological horror frays the senses as intensely as anything experienced inA Quiet Place.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: Why would you want another slavish translation when you have this level of frantic entertainment? An absolute cracker.
reviews.author: Donald Clarke

reviews.text: An intense and at times traumatic viewing experience, The Invisible Man proves once and for all that it's time Hollywood started taking Leigh Whannell very seriously.
reviews.author: Kat Hughes

reviews.text: Leigh Whannell's direction is noticeably sharper than his script, but the film remains a cracking thriller that turns up the tension with suspense, scares, and surprises.
reviews.author: Rob Hunter

reviews.text: This is post-feminist movie feminism. F*** the guy. He is the a**hole bad guy. He doesn't deserve the screen time. All we need to know is how she feels.
reviews.author: David Poland

reviews.text: A suspense thriller so strong that its minor flaws are barely visible. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Nestor Bentancor

reviews.text: Elizabeth Moss elevates a simplified version of H.G. Wells' classic tale into a higher level of thrills and scares
reviews.author: J. Don Birnam

reviews.text: An enjoyably nervy little slice of psychological horror whose best moments aren't its numerous jump scares (though they are, in fact, extremely jumpy) but the quieter, more existential ones.
reviews.author: Leah Greenblatt

reviews.text: If the weakest part of a suspense/sci-fi/thriller is the science fiction elements, we're all in a world of trouble.
reviews.author: Dwight Brown

reviews.text: Alive with fresh thinking from Whanell and a dynamite Elisabeth Moss, this socially conscious horrorshow tips the old monster mash into way scarier shit about toxic masculinity that's as timely as #MeToo and Harvey Weinstein in handcuffs.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: [Leigh Whannell] has streamlined his ingredients and kept it simple at its core, slowly building out the terror from there, resulting in an all-too-slick, psychological thriller that demands to be seen.
reviews.author: Peter Gray

reviews.text: A slow-moving thriller with too many blank spaces.
reviews.author: Rafer Guzman

reviews.text: Leigh Whannell's bleak and brutal reimagining of the classic Invisible Man is chillingly effective.
reviews.author: Rosie Knight

reviews.text: For an update of a Universal Monster, re-written as a villain who is universally recognizable, this is original, chilling and effective stuff. This Invisible Man is well worth seeing.
reviews.author: Rosie Fletcher

reviews.text: Leigh Whannell's The Invisible Man goes to show that the Universal Monster films can be adapted for modern audiences as long as they are in the hands of the right person.
reviews.author: Shannon McGrew

reviews.text: Effective both with its full-blown horror antics and as a depiction of the real-world abuse one can suffer, Whannell delivers an endlessly unsettling experience.
reviews.author: Patrick Cavanaugh

reviews.text: 'The Invisible Man' wins big by just letting its title monster be a monster through-and-through.
reviews.author: Scott Mendelson

reviews.text: Whannell realizes how much tension he can milk from long, uneasy scenes where Moss is stalking around a seemingly empty room.
reviews.author: Chris Evangelista

reviews.text: Like its style, The Invisible Man's cruelty is the point.
reviews.author: Ed Gonzalez

reviews.text: Delivers Hitchcock levels of tension, suspense and outright terror, and it's just a brilliant direction to go with the character.
reviews.author: Edward Douglas

reviews.text: The Invisible Man is a suspenseful thriller with a modern twist on a classic horror character. Elizabeth Moss steals the show with a haunting yet electrifying performance that will leave the audience on the edge of their seats.
reviews.author: Sharronda Williams

reviews.text: With steady character work banking our investment, Whannell tightens the screws to scare.
reviews.author: Kevin Harley

reviews.text: Unbearably tense and thematically rich, this feels like an entirely fresh take on a 123-year-old story. Which is not something we saw coming.
reviews.author: John Nugent

reviews.text: The Invisible Man addresses its underlying themes... with utmost seriousness and old-fashioned jump-scares; it's a haunted house ride with more on its mind than up its sleeve.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: Whannell has pulled off a truly arresting, up-to-the-moment take on old material that makes it feel as fresh and new as if it had been conceived today.
reviews.author: Huw Fullerton

reviews.text: A solid thriller with some nifty effects, a bunch of well-earned scares, and a riveting lead performance.
reviews.author: Angie Han

reviews.text: It's a #MeToo horror film that couldn't be any more timely if it shuffled into a courtroom with a Zimmer frame.
reviews.author: Philip De Semlyen

reviews.text: ...a triumph... a clever, engrossing and frequently genuinely scary genre flick with a stellar cast and thematic resonance.
reviews.author: Anthony O'Connor

reviews.text: The Invisible Man provides unrelenting tension from start to finish.
reviews.author: Matthew Toomey

reviews.text: Though Adrian's methods grow increasingly menacing (or is it all in her head?), "The Invisible Man" lacks for truly terrifying moments.
reviews.author: Jude Dry

reviews.text: There's fun to be had here, thanks to Moss and an involving set-up, and given the state of multiplex horror, especially at this time of year, this is a striking diversion.
reviews.author: Benjamin Lee

reviews.text: Whannell's canny screenplay knows that the audience is well ahead of Cecilia, and the sinister camerawork is on it too. Many a scene finds cinematographer Stefan Duscio's frame listing, with apparent aimlessness, to one side or another. \
reviews.author: William Bibbiani

reviews.text: Leigh Whannell focuses on just delivering a terrifying horror, and delivers the thrills.
reviews.author: Ian Sandwell

reviews.text: [I]t's an "Invisible Man" much more than a maniacal guy in gauze, for the better.
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: Whannell's Invisible Man is a sleek upgrade of his past horror work...
reviews.author: Jesse Hassenger

reviews.text: Not only a genuinely scary movie, but a brilliant sci-fi twist on the fear women too often feel. Leigh Whannell is quickly becoming a master filmmaker, and Moss shines.
reviews.author: Grace Randolph

reviews.text: "The Invisible Man" is devious fun, with a message that's organic enough to hit home: that in a toxic relationship, what you see is what you get - but what gets to you is what you don't see.
reviews.author: Owen Gleiberman

reviews.text: [A]s stressed, and distressed, as Cecilia is most of the time, Moss provides a core of inner strength that invites investment in her abilities and, ultimately, belief in her survival.
reviews.author: Todd McCarthy

reviews.text: Paranoid and terrifying, Whannell and Moss bring horror fans a visceral horror pic that does the legacy of the Universal Monsters proud.
reviews.author: Norman Gidney

reviews.text: Led by yet another impressive performance from Elisabeth Moss, 'The Invisible Man' is as thrilling and terrifying as it is shrewdly relevant.
reviews.author: Doug Jamieson

reviews.text: At the heart of what makes The Invisible Man work as well as it does is an ingenious approach to the specific terror that the monster can inspire...
reviews.author: Eric Eisenberg

reviews.text: Writer-director Leigh Whannell, screenwriter of Saw, has evolved into a proper illusionist with his old school yet radical retelling of The Invisible Man.
reviews.author: Simon Miraudo

reviews.text: The Invisible Man is not about what invisibility does to a man, it's about how an abuser can become even deadlier with invisibility. That's a terrifying new perspective.
reviews.author: Fred Topel

reviews.text: This Invisible Man is not entertainment; it's merely a domestic-violence showcase for masochists.
reviews.author: Armond White

synopsis: After staging his own suicide, a crazed scientist uses his power to become invisible to stalk and terrorize his ex-girlfriend. When the police refuse to believe her story, she decides to take matters into her own hands and fight back.
